messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 21:53:20, Wez wrote:
> typo: cross-platform -> cross-platform code

Done.

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: nit: Should these be DCHECKs?  Should there be a state == stopped check here, too?

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: nit: Are this and OnConfigWatcherError called on any particular thread?

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: nit: One thing that wasn't clear to me from the previous CL is that there's a convention that terminal IDs start from zero whenever the network process is started.  See my suggestions re terminal-ID handling, below.

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: nit: Seems really strange that we do IPC I/O on the non-I/O thread; perhaps clarify what the two are used for in the Create() comment?

messages.author: Wez
messages.text:
typo: the -> an
typo: be allocated -> have been allocated yet

messages.author: Wez
messages.text: This check gets progressively weaker as time goes on. Why not keep track (e.g. with std::set<>) of the IDs the network process has "connected", and clear them up when it asks to disconnect?

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 21:53:20, Wez wrote:
> nit: Should these be DCHECKs?

Done.

> Should there be a state == stopped check here, too?

It should be in the most derived class. It is present in DaemonProcessWin.

> nit: Are this and OnConfigWatcherError called on any particular thread?

Done.

> convention that terminal IDs start from zero whenever the network process is
> started.  See my suggestions re terminal-ID handling, below.

Ack.

messages.author: alexeypa (please no reviews)
messages.text:
On 2012/10/16 21:53:20, Wez wrote:
> nit: Seems really strange that we do IPC I/O on the non-I/O thread; 

This is how ChannelProxy works.

> clarify what the two are used for in the Create() comment?

I added the comment, but I'm getting too verbose. The purpose of both task runners is explained next to the corresponding data members definitions.

> This check gets progressively weaker as time goes on. Why not keep track (e.g.
> with std::set<>) of the IDs the network process has "connected", and clear them

The range is large enough and this check is simpler.
